name: Avoid Hype in Author Attribution
description: Do not hype a study by listing the names, credentials, institutions, or other 'qualifications' of their authors. Focus on the content of the study and its relevance to the gene or protein. Notable contributions can be mentioned in the discovery/history section.

name: Use UniProt Protein Name for Short Articles
description: For relatively short articles, use the recommended UniProt protein name as the article name.

name: Use Protein Acronym or HUGO Gene Symbol for Verbose Names
description: If the protein name is verbose, use either a widely used protein acronym or the official HUGO gene symbol followed by "(gene)" if needed for disambiguation.

name: Enumerate Proteins in a Family with a Dash and Arabic Number
description: When naming proteins grouped into a family based on homology or shared function, enumerate the different members with a dash "-" followed by an Arabic number (e.g., desmoglein-1, desmoglein-2, etc.).

name: Include Taxon for Viral Protein Articles
description: For articles about viral proteins, include the taxon in the title to avoid ambiguity. A parenthesized term added for disambiguation does not constitute unnecessary disambiguation.

name: Use Abbreviations for Gene Names
description: Abbreviations of genes should be used according to the HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee guidelines. Gene symbols should be written in italics, with full names also in italics. Abbreviations should be preferred over full names.

name: Capitalization of Gene Names
description: Human gene names should be written in all capitals (e.g., ALDOA, INS). For orthologs of human genes in other species, only the initial letter should be capitalized (e.g., mouse Aldoa, bovine Ins).

name: Recommended Usage of Gene Symbols
description: Recommended usages include: "the ALDOA gene is regulated...", "the rat gene for Aldoa is regulated...", "ALDOA is regulated...". It is not recommended to say "the gene ALDOA is regulated" as it is redundant.

name: Standard Format for Diagrams
description: Diagrams should adhere to a standard format. If the diagram guide lacks clear instructions on image style, consider proposing modifications to conform to standardized formatting guidelines.

name: Include Relevant Infoboxes
description: One or more of the specified infobox templates should be included at the top of each article based on the content being discussed.

name: Consider Additional Infoboxes for Exceptions
description: Consider adding additional infoboxes like enzyme or protein family infoboxes in specific cases where one human paralog is assigned to a particular EC number or Pfam family.

name: Define Scope in Lead Section
description: The first sentence of the lead section should clearly define the scope of the article.

name: Avoid Redundancy in Gene Section
description: Do not repeat basic gene information that is already present in the infobox unless it is especially notable.

name: Avoid Redundancy in Protein Section
description: Do not repeat basic protein information that is already present in the infobox unless it is especially notable.

name: Concisely Describe Species, Tissue, and Subcellular Distribution
description: Provide concise information about the species where the gene is expressed, the tissues where the protein is expressed, and the subcellular compartments/organelles where the protein is found.

name: Describe Protein Function
description: Clearly describe the function of the transcribed protein.

name: List Interactions in Interactions Section
description: List proteins that the subject protein interacts with in the Interactions section.

name: Highlight Clinical Significance
description: List diseases or conditions resulting from gene mutations or protein deficiencies/excesses in the Clinical Significance section.

name: Attribute Discoveries in History/Discovery
description: Attribute key discoveries concerning the gene or protein to the relevant individuals or groups in the History/Discovery section.

name: Linking to Wikidata Item
description: The Wikipedia article should be linked to a Wikidata item of the entity first mentioned in the first sentence of the lead section.

name: Wikidata Item for First Mentioned Entity
description: The Wikipedia article should be linked to a Wikidata item of the entity mentioned in the first sentence of the lead section.

name: Use Reliable Sources
description: Ensure that all sources cited are reliable and trustworthy. Refer to Wikipedia guidelines for identifying reliable sources in natural sciences and physical sciences, mathematics, and medicine.

name: Provide Inline Citations
description: Articles should contain dense inline citations using either footnotes or parenthetical citations to support statements. Avoid adding textbooks as general references without specific citations.

name: Maintain Consistent Citation Format
description: While there is no standard citation format on Wikipedia, ensure consistency in citation format within each article. Editors can format citations manually or use citation templates for control and presentation.

name: Include Hyperlinks in Citations
description: Supply hyperlinks in citations where applicable, such as linking to journal abstracts on PubMed, using DOI templates, and linking to freely available full-text articles online. Prefer HTML links over PDF when both are available.

name: Include Navigation Boxes for Related Proteins
description: Articles about related proteins should include one or more navigation boxes to cross link them appropriately. Examples of navigation boxes may include Cytoskeletal Proteins, Ion channels, Transcription factors, and Transmembrane receptors.

name: Categorization Requirement
description: Every Wikipedia article should be added to at least one category. Specific categories or subcategories that may be appropriate for gene and protein articles are provided, including Proteins, Enzymes by function, and Genes by human chromosome.

name: Consistent Formatting of Notes
description: Maintain a consistent and clear formatting style for notes throughout the article to enhance readability and coherence.
